The Government has decided to set up an independent
Committee of Inquiry to report on the salaries and allowances paid
to Senators and Members of the Commonwealth Parliament and also to
report generally on related matters,
It will be recalled that both the Committees which have
previously examined anu reported on these matters the first in
1951/ 52 under the Chairmanship of the late Mr. Justice Nicholas and
that of 1955 chc iled by Sir Frank Richardson recommended a review s.

periodic review of Parliamentary salaries is necessary irrespecti
of the way in which changes are made and in fact whether any
* changes are made.' In the course of the last Parliament, my
colleague the Tres su-er, The it. Hon. Harola Holt, in his capacity
as Leader of the House to Members that review of these
* matters should be made early in the life of each new Parliament and
subject only to quite abnormal-circumstances the. conditions then
determined should ap[ ly . anchanged throughout the life of that
Parliament. Th is ' rie -: iew of the Government. It has discussed
the arrangements now proposed with the Leader of the Opposition, the
Rt. Hon. Dr. H. V. Evatt, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition,
the Hon. A. A. Calwell.
Salaries and conditions of Senators and Members were last
reviewed in 1955, ind the last review of the emoluments of Ministers
and office bearers of the Parliament was made in 1952.
SThe terms of reference of the Committee will be
To enquire into and report upon the salaries and
allowances payable to Senators and Members of the
House of Representatives, including those paid to
Ministers and Members who are office bearers of the
Parliament.
If it be reported that it is necessary or desirable to
alter such salaries and allowance or any of them,
then to recom-end the nature and extent of the
alterations that should be made.
